keyTakeAways: The last government shutdown (Dec 2018 â€“ Jan 2019) was the longest in nearly 50 years, lasting 35 days.
It cost the U.S. an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP according to the Congressional Budget Office.
The current shutdown is a full government shutdown, unlike the 2018 event, which was partial, as no 12 appropriations bills have been passed.
During the 2018 shutdown, about 800,000 federal employees were affected, with approximately 300,000 furloughed and 500,000 exempted (required to work without pay).
The current shutdown occurs amid a highly partisan Congress, with narrow majorities and lack of supermajority votes in the Senate, making bipartisan compromise difficult.
Republican Speaker Mike Johnson oversees a House majority considered one of the narrowest in history, contributing to stalled negotiations.
The lack of a funding deal means that all federal operations are suspended, affecting public services and national operations.
Government shutdowns have declined in frequency since 1990, but political polarization has made sustained funding disputes more likely.

namedEntities.name: United States federal government
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The central executive branch of the U.S. government responsible for administering national policy and services
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The entity is directly involved in the current shutdown, as it has been fully closed due to lack of funding appropriations.

namedEntities.name: Congressional Budget Office (CBO)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nonpartisan agency that provides economic and fiscal analysis to Congress
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The CBO estimated that the 2018 shutdown cost the U.S. $3 billion in lost GDP, providing authoritative economic context to the shutdown's impact.

namedEntities.name: Republican Speaker Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives, currently leading the Republican majority
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His leadership in a narrow House majority has contributed to the difficulty of passing funding legislation and negotiating a shutdown resolution.

namedEntities.name: Senate filibuster
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A procedural rule in the U.S. Senate that allows extended debate to delay or block legislation
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The GOP lacks the 60 votes needed to overcome a filibuster, which impedes bipartisan efforts to pass funding bills and end the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Capitol Hill
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The legislative complex where Congress meets and conducts policy debates
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The failure to resolve funding issues on Capitol Hill is the direct cause of the ongoing government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: 12 appropriations bills
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A set of legislative bills required to fund different federal departments and agencies
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The absence of passage of all 12 appropriations bills is the legal and procedural reason for the current full government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: 35 days
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The duration of the 2018 government shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This period was the longest in nearly 50 years and set a precedent for the severity of political gridlock in U.S. fiscal policy.

namedEntities.name: 800,000 federal employees
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The workforce affected during the 2018 shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The scale of workforce impact illustrates the human and economic consequences of a government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: 300,000 furloughed employees
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal workers who were not paid and instructed not to report to work during the 2018 shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Furloughed employees represent a direct human cost of shutdowns, with implications for public trust and employee morale.

namedEntities.name: 300,000 exempted employees
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal workers required to report to work but not paid during the 2018 shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Exempted employees illustrate how even minimal operations can be disrupted during funding lapses.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major international news network providing real-time coverage of political events
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: CNN reported on and updated the status of the shutdown, providing public awareness and context to the crisis.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. government is currently in a full shutdown due to Congress failing to pass any of the 12 required appropriations bills. This follows the 2018 shutdown, which was the longest in nearly 50 years, lasting 35 days and costing an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP. In that previous event, about 800,000 federal employees were affected, with 300,000 furloughed and 500,000 exempted. The current shutdown reflects deepening political polarization, with narrow majorities and a lack of Senate supermajority votes to overcome a filibuster. Republican Speaker Mike Johnson oversees a historically narrow House majority, making bipartisan compromise difficult. This situation highlights how partisan gridlock on Capitol Hill can disrupt essential federal services and have significant economic and social consequences.
